Typhoid fever is a bacterial infection caused by Salmonella typhi and is typically transmitted through contaminated food or water.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rubella: Congenital rubella syndrome infection will have a triad of CCD congenital heart disease (PDA), cataract & deafness.

 

Option C. Rabies: For rabies there should be a history of hydrophobia with history of dog bite.

 

Option D. Typhoid: Typhoid fever will have rose like spots on trunk on 7th day of fever, relative bradychardia, step ladder pattern of fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Warthin-Finkeldey cells are pathognomonic giant multinucleated cells associated with measles (rubeola) infection and are indicative of viral interaction with lymphoid tissue, aiding in the diagnosis of this highly contagious respiratory illness.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in Downs syndrome?  (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Caudal regression syndrome

 

  • Caudal regression syndrome is not typically associated with Down syndrome. Caudal regression syndrome is a congenital disorder characterized by abnormal development of the lower spine (caudal region). It is a separate condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypothyroidism: Hypothyroidism is a known association with Down syndrome. 

 

Option B. Hearing loss: Hearing loss is commonly observed in individuals with Down syndrome. Ear infections and structural abnormalities may contribute to this condition.

 

Option C. Short stature: Short stature is a characteristic feature of Down syndrome. Individuals with Down syndrome often have a shorter stature compared to the general population.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the common clinical features and associated conditions of Down syndrome. Understand that hypothyroidism, hearing loss, and short stature are commonly observed in individuals with Down syndrome. Be aware of the distinct features of other congenital conditions, such as caudal regression syndrome, that are not typically associated with Down syndrome.

questions.text: The hormone that does not play a role in the growth of the fetus is: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Growth hormone.

 

Fetal growth is a complex process regulated by various hormones, but growth hormone does not play a significant role in this process during fetal life. The primary hormones involved in fetal growth include insulin, thyroxine, and glucocorticoids.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Insulin: Insulin is crucial for fetal growth, especially during the third trimester. It plays a key role in promoting the storage of nutrients and the growth of fetal tissues, particularly adipose tissue and muscle.
  • Thyroxine: Fetal production of thyroxine begins around the 12th week of gestation. Thyroxine is vital for the development of the central nervous system and overall growth and differentiation of tissues.
  • Glucocorticoids: Glucocorticoids are essential towards the end of gestation, particularly for the maturation of organs such as the lungs, liver, and gastrointestinal tract. They help prepare the fetus for life outside the womb by stimulating the production of surfactant in the lungs and facilitating the maturation of other critical systems.
  • Growth Hormone: Unlike in postnatal life, where growth hormone is a key regulator of growth, its role in fetal growth is minimal. Fetal growth is largely driven by insulin and other growth factors rather than growth hormone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Insulin and Option C. Thyroxine: Both are crucial for fetal growth, regulating tissue growth and differentiation, especially in the later stages of pregnancy.

 

Option D. Glucocorticoids: These hormones are essential for the maturation of fetal organs before birth, particularly in the liver, lungs, and gastrointestinal tract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Growth hormone does not play a significant role in fetal growth, which is primarily regulated by insulin, thyroxine, and glucocorticoids.

questions.text: Which of the following is an X-linked disorder? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Color blindness

 

Among the options given, color blindness is an X-linked disorder.

 

Color blindness is a condition in which an individual has difficulty distinguishing between different colors. It is caused by a genetic mutation that affects the development or function of the photopigments in the retina of the eye.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thalassemia: Thalassemia, sickle cell anemia, and cystic fibrosis are not X-linked disorders. They are all Autosomal recessive inheritance. Thalassemia is an inherited blood disorder that affects the production of hemoglobin, a protein in red blood cells that carries oxygen.

 

Option C. Sickle cell anemia: Sickle cell anemia is also an inherited blood disorder that affects the production of hemoglobin, leading to the formation of abnormal, sickle-shaped red blood cells.

 

Option D. Cystic fibrosis: Cystic fibrosis is an inherited disorder that affects the production and function of mucus, leading to the buildup of thick, sticky mucus in the lungs and other organs.

 

These conditions are inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, meaning that both parents must carry a mutated gene to pass the condition on to their children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Color blindness is an X-linked disorder, meaning that the gene causing the condition is located on the X chromosome, which primarily affects males and is passed down from carrier mothers.

questions.text: A neonate presents with post feed vomiting and hypoglycemia in the first week of life. Urine was positive for reducing substances but there was no glucose and urine also gave positive reaction with Benedicts reagent. The neonate also had reversible oil drop cataract. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Classical Galactosemia


Classical Galactosemia is the correct diagnosis based on the clinical presentation. It is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase (GALT), which is crucial in the metabolism of galactose. This enzyme deficiency leads to the accumulation of galactose and its toxic metabolites, causing the symptoms observed in the neonate.

 

  • Symptoms: The neonate presents with post-feed vomiting, hypoglycemia, and cataracts, which are hallmark features of classical galactosemia.
  • Urine findings: The positive reaction with Benedicts reagent indicates the presence of reducing substances, specifically galactose, in the urine. The absence of glucose further supports the diagnosis.
  • Cataracts: The reversible oil drop cataract is a classic sign of galactosemia, caused by the accumulation of galactitol in the lens of the eye.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Essential Fructosuria: Essential fructosuria is a benign condition due to fructokinase deficiency, leading to the presence of fructose in the urine. It does not cause the severe symptoms seen in galactosemia, such as hypoglycemia or cataracts.

 

Option C. Galactokinase Deficiency: Galactokinase deficiency can also lead to the accumulation of galactose, but it typically presents with cataracts alone and does not cause the severe systemic symptoms such as vomiting and hypoglycemia seen in classical galactosemia.

 

Option D. Uridine diphosphate-glucose 4-epimerase deficiency: This is a rare condition that affects the conversion of UDP-galactose to UDP-glucose. Its clinical presentation can vary but does not typically include the combination of severe hypoglycemia, vomiting, and cataracts associated with classical galactosemia.

 

Educational Objective:


Recognize the clinical features and diagnostic findings associated with classical galactosemia, including post-feed vomiting, hypoglycemia, positive reducing substances in urine, positive reaction with Benedicts reagent, and the development of reversible oil drop cataracts.

questions.text: At 6 weeks of life, a child developed a fever after DPT vaccination. And now child is 10 weeks due for vaccination. What should be done next? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Give DPT Vaccination

 

  • Fever following a DPT vaccination does not necessarily contraindicate subsequent doses. The child should receive the next scheduled DPT vaccination unless there are specific contraindications or severe adverse reactions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Give DT: Giving only DT (Diphtheria and Tetanus) without the pertussis component may not be ideal for overall protection against these diseases. It's important to provide the complete vaccination schedule, including DPT, unless contraindications exist.

 

Option C. Dont give DPT: This may not be the best course of action. Fever following the initial DPT vaccination is not an absolute contraindication to subsequent doses. The child should continue the vaccination schedule unless there are specific contraindications.

 

Option D. Dont give any vaccination: This is not the recommended approach. Missing or delaying vaccinations may leave the child susceptible to vaccine-preventable diseases. It's important to adhere to the recommended vaccination schedule whenever possible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the approach to managing adverse events following immunization. Recognize that mild reactions, such as fever after a vaccine, do not necessarily contraindicate subsequent doses. Adherence to the recommended vaccination schedule is crucial for providing timely and effective protection against vaccine-preventable diseases

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Neonates who are asymptomatic at birth have a lesser risk of later sequelae.
  2. 20-40% are symptomatic at birth.
  3. In developing countries, the rate of transmission of CMV infection to the infant is more common from primary maternal infection than reactivation.
  4. Diagnosis by urine specimen at 4 weeks of age
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3

 

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a common congenital infection, and understanding the nuances of its transmission, diagnosis, and clinical implications is important.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Congenital CMV Infection:
    • Transmission: Congenital CMV infection can occur from either primary maternal infection (which is when the mother is infected with CMV for the first time during pregnancy) or from reactivation of a prior CMV infection in the mother. The risk of transmission to the fetus is significantly higher in cases of primary maternal infection (around 30%) compared to reactivation (about 1-2%). In developing countries, the prevalence of CMV reactivation is higher, but primary infection remains the more significant source of transmission to the fetus.
    • Asymptomatic vs. Symptomatic: The majority of neonates with congenital CMV are asymptomatic at birth, and these asymptomatic infants have a lower risk of developing long-term sequelae such as sensorineural hearing loss compared to those who are symptomatic at birth.
    • Clinical Presentation: About 10% of neonates with congenital CMV infection are symptomatic at birth. Symptoms can include hepatosplenomegaly, petechial rash, jaundice, chorioretinitis, microcephaly, and thrombocytopenia. These symptoms are associated with a higher risk of long-term complications.
    • Diagnosis: CMV infection can be diagnosed by detecting the virus in urine, saliva, or blood within the first three weeks of life. Diagnosis at four weeks, as mentioned in option 4, is less likely to be reliable because it may represent postnatal infection rather than congenital infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B (1, 2): The percentage of neonates symptomatic at birth is around 10%, not 20-40%.

 

Option C (2, 4): The diagnosis by urine specimen at four weeks is not ideal, and the percentage of symptomatic neonates at birth is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neonates who are asymptomatic at birth from congenital CMV infection have a lower risk of long-term sequelae, and transmission is more common from primary maternal infection than from reactivation, especially in developing countries.

questions.text:
An unconscious child is brought to the casualty. What is the correct sequence of the management? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Assess breathing
  2. Assess pulse
  3. Assess response
  4. Start compressions
  5. Bag and mask ventilation
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3-1-2-4-5

 

When managing an unconscious child, especially in a potential cardiac or respiratory arrest scenario, it is crucial to follow the steps of Basic Life Support (BLS) in the correct sequence to ensure the best chance of recovery.

 

 

Sequence Justification:

 

  • The correct sequence is 3-1-2-4-5, which means:
    • 3: First, assess response (to determine unresponsiveness).
    • 1: Then assess breathing (to check for normal breathing).
    • 2: Followed by assessing the pulse (to check for circulation).
    • 4: Start compressions if necessary (if no pulse or poor perfusion).
    • 5: Provide bag and mask ventilation to support breathing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In BLS, the correct sequence of actions is crucial for effective management. Start by assessing response, followed by breathing and pulse, then initiate compressions and ventilation as needed.

questions.text: Identify the condition. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Jejunal atresia

 

The image provided shows a characteristic "triple bubble" sign, which is indicative of jejunal atresia. Jejunal atresia is a congenital condition where there is an absence or closure of a portion of the jejunum, leading to intestinal obstruction.

 

The radiographic finding of the triple bubble sign is due to the accumulation of gas in the stomach, duodenum, and the proximal jejunum, which are isolated by the atresia from the rest of the intestines. This results in three distinct gas-filled areas visible on the X-ray, hence the term "triple bubble."

 

In the context of the provided options, the diagnosis is most consistent with jejunal atresia based on this radiographic sign.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyloric stenosis: Pyloric stenosis typically presents with a "single bubble" sign on X-ray, representing gas in the stomach only due to obstruction at the level of the pylorus.

 

Option B. Duodenal atresia: Duodenal atresia presents with a "double bubble" sign, showing two gas-filled areas (stomach and duodenum) separated by the atresia. This is different from the triple bubble sign seen in jejunal atresia.

 

Option D. Intestinal obstruction: While intestinal obstruction can cause various radiographic signs, the specific "triple bubble" sign is most characteristic of jejunal atresia rather than a general obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "triple bubble" sign on an X-ray is indicative of jejunal atresia, a congenital obstruction of the jejunum.

questions.text: Which of the following is the additional component in the pentalogy of Fallot? (NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Atrial septal defect (ASD)

 

Explanation:

 

The pentology of Fallot includes the four defects found in the tetralogy of Fallot (ventricular septal defect, right ventricular hypertrophy, pulmonic stenosis, and overriding of aorta) plus an additional defect, which is usually an atrial septal defect (ASD) or a patent foramen ovale. This additional component distinguishes the pentology from the tetralogy of Fallot.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ventricular septal defect (VSD): This is one of the four defects in the tetralogy of Fallot, not an additional component.

 

Option C. Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH): This is also part of the tetralogy of Fallot.

 

Option D. Pulmonic stenosis: Another component of the tetralogy of Fallot, not an additional component.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pentology of Fallot includes the four defects of the tetralogy of Fallot plus an atrial septal defect (ASD).

questions.text: Calculate the mid parental height of a male patient with father height 183 cm and mother height 175 cm? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 185.5

 

The mid-parental height (MPH) is a method used to estimate the potential adult height of a child based on the heights of the parents.

 

Formula:

 

Using the given heights:

 

  • Father's height = 183 cm
  • Mother's height = 175 cm
  • MPH = [(183+175)/2] + 6.5 = 185.5

 

Therefore, the mid-parental height is 185.5 cm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To calculate the mid-parental height for a male child, use the formula:

 

(Fathers height+Mothers height)/2+6.5 cm.

questions.text: Molecular defect causing liver disease in Dubin-Johnson syndrome is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ABCC2

 

Molecular defect causing liver disease in Dubin-Johnson syndrome is ABCC2 (codes for canalicular protein with ATP-binding cassette), it leads to the mutation of multiple drug-resistant protein 2 (MRP2) receptor. Hence, there is a defect in the transfer of conjugated bilirubin from the liver to bile in Dubin-Johnson syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ATP7A: This gene is associated with Menkes disease, a disorder of copper metabolism.

 

Option B. ATP7B: This gene is associated with Wilson's disease, another disorder of copper metabolism.

 

Option D. SERPINA1: This gene is associated with Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, a condition that can lead to liver and lung disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The molecular defect causing liver disease in Dubin-Johnson syndrome is in the ABCC2 gene, which encodes for a canalicular protein involved in the excretion of conjugated bilirubin.

questions.text: According to current recommended dietary guidelines for children, energy from saturated fats should be of total energy intake: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) < 10%

 

According to current dietary guidelines for children, energy from saturated fats should be <10% of total energy intake.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

According to current dietary guidelines for children, energy from saturated fats should be less than 10% of total energy intake.

choices.text: Follows autosomal dominant mode of inheritance

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding ataxia-telangiectasia? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Follows autosomal dominant mode inheritance

 

The mode of inheritance in ataxia-telangiectasia is autosomal recessive.

 

Ataxia telangiectasia:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ataxia-telangiectasia is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the ATM gene on chromosome 11, characterized by defective DNA repair, immunodeficiency, progressive neurological degeneration, and increased risk of malignancies.

questions.text:
Which of the following cyanotic heart diseases causes increased pulmonary blood flow? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Ebstein anomaly
  2. Tetralogy of Fallot
  3. Transposition of the great arteries (TGA)
  4. Total anomalous pulmonary venous communication (TAPVC)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3, 4

 

Transposition of the great arteries (TGA) and total anomalous pulmonary venous communication (TAPVC) are both cyanotic congenital heart diseases that cause increased pulmonary blood flow.

 

3. Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA): In TGA, the positions of the pulmonary artery and the aorta are switched, which results in deoxygenated blood being circulated throughout the body. The mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood occurs, leading to increased pulmonary blood flow because the deoxygenated blood is directed to the lungs.

 

4. Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Communication (TAPVC): In TAPVC, the pulmonary veins do not connect normally to the left atrium. Instead, they connect to the right atrium or systemic veins, causing a mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood. This also leads to increased blood flow to the lungs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1, 4: Ebstein anomaly does not cause increased pulmonary blood flow. Ebstein anomaly involves downward displacement of the tricuspid valve, leading to decreased pulmonary blood flow.

 

Option B. 1, 2: Both Ebstein anomaly and Tetralogy of Fallot cause decreased pulmonary blood flow. Tetralogy of Fallot includes pulmonary stenosis, which limits blood flow to the lungs.

 

Option D. 2, 4: Tetralogy of Fallot causes decreased pulmonary blood flow due to the presence of pulmonary stenosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cyanotic congenital heart diseases such as Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA) and Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Communication (TAPVC) cause increased pulmonary blood flow.
